required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Metanx® in Subjects With Type 2 Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy (DPN)
clinical_study.official_title: A 24 Week, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Multisite Study of Metanx® in Subjects With Type 2 Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy (DPN)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to determine if Metanx improves sensory neuropathy in persons with Type 2 diabetes. Metanx is a medical food available with a prescription from a physician. It consists of L-methylfolate, Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate, and Methylcobalamin, which are the active forms of folate, vitamin B6, and vitamin B12, respectively. Subjects will be randomly assigned to receive either Metanx or placebo for 6 months.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Vibration Perception Threshold (VPT) at 24 Weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: VPT was measured a 0 (baseline), and 24 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Vibration Perception Threshold (VPT) 25-45 volts at hallux on either leg as measured by VPT meter on the great toe of each foot. Mean VPT averaged across both toes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Neuropathy Total Symptom Score-6 (NTSS-6)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: NTSS-6 scores were taken at 0 (Baseline), 16, and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: This measure was taken to determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) changes neuropathic symptoms as evaluated by the Neuropathy Total Symptom Score-6 (NTSS-6) The Neuropathy Total Symptom Score-6 Scale (NTSS-6) is a validated scale that evaluates individual neuropathy sensory symptoms in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) and diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN). This scale was a modified 6 item scale that consists of yes or no questions. Scores range between 0 and 21.96, a higher score indicates greater severity of symptoms. After adjusting for baseline measurements scores are reflected as negative numbers. Negative numbers indicate improvement in symptoms. ie. a change from baseline after 24 weeks of -2 would be a greater improvement than a change in baseline of -1 after 24 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Neuropathy Disability Score (NDS)at Week 16 and 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: NDS scores were taken at 0 (Baseline), 16, and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: This outcome was taken to determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) has an effect on clinical examination as determined by the Neuropathy Disability Score (NDS) The Neuropathy Disability Score (NDS) evaluates the severity of individual symptoms of neuropathy. A simple visual numeric distress scale is used that ranges from 0 to 10. The most favorable score is 0, which indicates an absence of symptoms. The most severe symptoms possible would be recorded as a score of 10.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Plasma Marker Levels of Total Folate and Total Methyl Malonic Acid (MMA) at Week 16 and 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Plasma Marker Levels at 0 (Baseline), 16, and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects a change in subject's total folate and total methyl malonic acid (MMA) at week 16 and 24

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in SF-36 MCS and SF-36 PCS at Week 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: SF-36 MCS and SF-36 PCS scores were measured at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects a subject's "quality of life" as determined by the SF-36 questionnaire The Short Form- 36 Mental Component Summary (SF-36 MCS) and SF-36 Physical Component Summary (SF-36 PCS) both measure health related quality of life, the MCS quantifying mental health and the PCS quantifying physical function. They are both scored on 100 point scales with 0 representing the worst possible outcome and 100 representing the most optimal possible scoring

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in 10-point Visual Analog Scale(VAS) at Week 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: VAS scores were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects a subject's lower extremity pain level using a 10-point Visual Analog Scale at Baseline and 24-week evaluation visits. The Visual Analog Scale (VAS) measures a patients sensation of pain. A 10-cm visual analog scale is used. A measurement on the 10 cm analog scale is used to quantify the level of pain indicated with 0 cm indicating "no pain" and 10 cm indicating the "worst pain imaginable".

secondary_outcome.measure: (Exploratory) Change From Baseline in Levels of IL-6 and TNF-α, at Week 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Analyte levels were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: (Exploratory) To determine if Metanx® affects a subject's plasma oxidative stress and inflammatory marker levels, including IL-6 and TNF-α

secondary_outcome.measure: (Exploratory) Change From Baseline in the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) Question Inventory at Week 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: HADS Scores scores were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) consists of a 14-item questionnaire that provides a measurement of depression. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale, giving a maximum scores of 21 for the most severe depression. Depression was evaluated using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) question inventory at Baseline, and 24-week evaluation visits

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Total Homocysteine at Week 16 and 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Plasma Marker Levels at 0 (Baseline), 16, and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects change in subjects total homocysteine levels

secondary_outcome.measure: (Exploratory) Change From Baseline in Levels of Hs-CRP at Week 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Analyte levels were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: (Exploratory) To determine if Metanx® affects a subject's plasma oxidative stress and inflammatory markers levels including hs-CRP

secondary_outcome.measure: (Exploratory) Change From Baseline in Levels Potential Antioxidant (PAO) at Week 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Analyte levels were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: (Exploratory) To determine if Metanx® affects a subject's plasma oxidative stress and inflammatory markers levels including Potential Antioxidant (PAO)

intervention.description: Metanx one tablet twice a day
Metanx placebo one tablet twice a day

facility.name: University of Alabama at Birmingham School of Medicine

results_reference.citation: Fonseca VA, Lavery LA, Thethi TK, Daoud Y, DeSouza C, Ovalle F, Denham DS, Bottiglieri T, Sheehan P, Rosenstock J. Metanx in type 2 diabetes with peripheral neuropathy: a randomized trial. Am J Med. 2013 Feb;126(2):141-9. doi: 10.1016/j.amjmed.2012.06.022. Epub 2012 Dec 5.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Of 373 patients screened, 214 entered the study , and 200 completed. The study was conducted at 6 participating U.S. sites
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Inclusion criteria included individuals 25 and 80 years of age, documented diabetes Type 2, Peripheral polyneuropathy, adequate lower extremity vascular status, and subject competence. 17 exclusion criteria including an HbA1c >9, uncontrolled heart or lung disease, and vitamin B supplementation, contributed to the number of screening failures.

group.title: Metanx
group.description: Patients aged 25 to 80 years with type 2 diabetes and neuropathy, were given Metanx (L-methylfolate calcium 3 mg, methylcobalamin 2 mg, and pyridoxal-5'-phosphate 35 mg (LMF-MC-PLP)) one tablet twice a day.

group.description: Patients aged 25 to 80 years with type 2 diabetes and neuropathy, were given Placebo, one tablet twice a day

This scale was a modified 6 item scale that consists of yes or no questions. Scores range between 0 and 21.96, a higher score indicates greater severity of symptoms. After adjusting for baseline measurements scores are reflected as negative numbers. Negative numbers indicate improvement in symptoms. ie. a change from baseline after 24 weeks of -2 would be a greater improvement than a change in baseline of -1 after 24 weeks.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in SF-36 MCS and SF-36 PCS at Week 24
outcome.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects a subject’s “quality of life” as determined by the SF-36 questionnaire The Short Form- 36 Mental Component Summary (SF-36 MCS) and SF-36 Physical Component Summary (SF-36 PCS) both measure health related quality of life, the MCS quantifying mental health and the PCS quantifying physical function. They are both scored on 100 point scales with 0 representing the worst possible outcome and 100 representing the most optimal possible scoring
outcome.time_frame: SF-36 MCS and SF-36 PCS scores were measured at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks

measure.title: Change From Baseline in SF-36 MCS and SF-36 PCS at Week 24
measure.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects a subject’s “quality of life” as determined by the SF-36 questionnaire The Short Form- 36 Mental Component Summary (SF-36 MCS) and SF-36 Physical Component Summary (SF-36 PCS) both measure health related quality of life, the MCS quantifying mental health and the PCS quantifying physical function. They are both scored on 100 point scales with 0 representing the worst possible outcome and 100 representing the most optimal possible scoring

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in 10-point Visual Analog Scale(VAS) at Week 24
outcome.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects a subject’s lower extremity pain level using a 10-point Visual Analog Scale at Baseline and 24-week evaluation visits. The Visual Analog Scale (VAS) measures a patients sensation of pain. A 10-cm visual analog scale is used. A measurement on the 10 cm analog scale is used to quantify the level of pain indicated with 0 cm indicating "no pain" and 10 cm indicating the "worst pain imaginable".
outcome.time_frame: VAS scores were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks

group.title: Metanx
group.description: Patients aged 25 to 80 years with type 2 diabetes and neuropathy, were given Metanx (L-methylfolate calcium 3 mg, methylcobalamin 2 mg, and pyridoxal-5'-phosphate 35 mg (LMF-MC-PLP)) one tablet twice a day.

measure.description: To determine if Metanx® (compared to placebo) affects a subject’s lower extremity pain level using a 10-point Visual Analog Scale at Baseline and 24-week evaluation visits. The Visual Analog Scale (VAS) measures a patients sensation of pain. A 10-cm visual analog scale is used. A measurement on the 10 cm analog scale is used to quantify the level of pain indicated with 0 cm indicating "no pain" and 10 cm indicating the "worst pain imaginable".

outcome.time_frame: Analyte levels were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks

outcome.title: (Exploratory) Change From Baseline in the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) Question Inventory at Week 24
outcome.description: The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) consists of a 14-item questionnaire that provides a measurement of depression. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale, giving a maximum scores of 21 for the most severe depression. Depression was evaluated using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) question inventory at Baseline, and 24-week evaluation visits
outcome.time_frame: HADS Scores scores were taken at 0 (Baseline) and 24 weeks

reported_events.time_frame: Reported Adverse Events (AEs) included events starting on or after the baseline visit until 4 weeks after the last study visit on week 24. The total duration of AE monitoring was 196 days.
reported_events.desc: An adverse event is any undesirable sign, symptom or medical condition occurring after starting study drug, even if the event is not considered to be related to study drug. Adverse Event reporting was provided only with specificity to the affected Organ System. Additional detail was not available at the time of reporting.

group.title: Metanx
group.description: Metanx one tablet twice a day

group.description: Placebo one tablet twice a day

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: General disorders and administration site conditions

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Investigators agreed to delay publication of study results until after multi-center results were published or, a period of up to 20 months had elapsed after termination of the study, whichever shall occur first.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Adverse Event reporting detailed in the “Other Adverse Events” section was provided only with specificity to the affected Organ System. Additional detail for the “Other Adverse Events” was not available at the time of reporting.
